By 2013, BHP Billiton's tax-free profits from its Singapore marketing hub were able to pay for a quarter of the dividend paid to shareholders of its British-listed Plc company.

11:19 am
PM

U.S. MOVES TO RESTRICT FOREIGN DEALS INTENDED TO AVOID TAXES The Treasury Department took additional steps on Monday to discourage American companies from making foreign acquisitions so that they can move overseas for a lower tax rate, Leslie Picker and Michael J. de la Merced report in DealBook. The Treasury Department had issued rules in September 2014 and in November to restrict this type of acquisition, known as a corporate inversion, but the measures announced on Monday are aimed at what the government calls "serial inverters," or foreign companies that have bulked up through multiple deals with American companies in a short period. The new rules threaten Pfizer's proposed $150 billion takeover of Allergan, a drug maker based in Dublin. Though the Pfizer-Allergan deal is not structured as an inversion (technically Allergan is the acquirer and Pfizer is the target), it still achieves the same goal of a lower tax rate abroad.

PM

That 's from Dealbook

BE

Yup, it's very specifically targeted to stop Pfizer and Allergan.

11:23 am
BE

Treasury action expected to materially impact PFE/AGN inversion: Temporary
regulations issued by the Treasury Department effective against transactions closing after
yesterday are expected to adversely impact the merger of Pfizer and Allergan (AGN,
$277.55, NC). More specifically, the rules could limit the ability of “serial inverters” to
perform subsequent transactions by disregarding foreign parent stock attributable to recent
inversions or acquisitions of US companies when measuring whether they meet the size
thresholds required to qualify. As of the time of writing Pfizer is still evaluating the impact
of the new regulations on the merger with Allergan and has not yet issued any statement
regarding its implications.

BE

Pfizer may not react as expected in terms of strategy: A scenario like this has been
contemplated by the stock market in recent times. The conventional wisdom is that Pfizer
stock should have a neutral to positive reaction to the announcement given the technical
impact of the risk-arb community position reversal that should take place as well as the
potential for Pfizer to accelerate the separation of Global Established Pharmaceuticals (GEP)
back on to a 2016 time-frame in terms of the decision making process. We are not sure that
we fully agree with the latter point, although it is a potential scenario. Others may speculate
that Pfizer could look to still complete the deal on an 80:20 inversion basis, but we feel this
is unlikely given the lower accretion and delayed access to Pfizer's overseas cash that this
would imply.
GEP separation may not be the fallback position: We have maintained right since
the separation of GEP was initially considered by management that this made most sense
in an inverted company structure, given that we estimate that the majority of GEP’s profits
are made overseas. We believe that the value proposition of a separated GEP would be
largely tied to its potential cash flow/dividend stream, which relies on an inverted structure
to maximize the amount of cash that can be returned to investors.

BE

Inversion options may still exist, but feels exhausted for now: Should Pfizer
management determine that an inversion with Allergan no longer make sense for the
company, we still see other potential options. GlaxoSmithKline (GSK LN, 1,428p, Hold),
or potentially even AstraZeneca (AZN LN, 3,971p, Hold) second time around could be
considered, given that they are not impacted by the new three year size rule. However, the
inversion story feels tired now that the Treasury has twice thwarted Large-Cap Pharma deals.
Awaiting direction from management: Our $42 Price Target for Pfizer is based on
50:50 weighted standalone ($38) and pro forma ($46) valuations. At present we have not
made any changes to this, but clearly if the merger with Allergan is now dead then we
may have to revert back towards our standalone valuation. We await further updates from
Pfizer management both on the merger with Allergan as well as any updates regarding the
potential separation timing for GEP, though we do not expect to hear anything on the latter
in the near term. We see few other key catalysts for Pfizer in 2016 outside of the Allergan
merger and potential GEP separation story updates and expect trading in the shares to be
dominated by news flow on these issues in the near term.

11:23 am
BE

And Wells Fargo.

BE

 In the past two weeks, we met with the CEO’s of both AGN and PFE, and we
believe that both were hopeful the merger would close, but appropriately cautious
to underscore risks, including then-unknown potential action by the Treasury.
Both companies mentioned that if the deal required a potentially distracting and
long legal battle, then they would have to reconsider the merits in this light.
 To us, whether PFE and AGN stay committed will be known shortly--more
important for many is if the deal breaks, where should AGN trade? Our initial
reaction is that if the deal breaks, AGN will be left as a standalone company with
strong earnings growth, a great pipeline, and after the Teva deal, will have a solid
balance sheet, in our view. We believe a 2017 S&P500 market multiple (15.3x)
applied to AGN’s 2017E EPS $17.54, or approximately $268 per share, is
appropriate as a non-DCF approach of where AGN should trade.

BE

 Teva sees no implications of the new rules on the TEVA-AGN generics deal and
sees nothing in the new rules that puts the TEVA-AGN generics deal in jeopardy,
and they are moving “full steam ahead.”
 The part we are most interested in is determining what implications, if any, the
new “earnings stripping” rules have on base earnings for AGN and other
companies in the sector. We have reached out to TEVA, MNK, PRGO and each
noted to us they are currently reviewing the implications. This uncertainty will
likely weigh on sector sentiment until this is clarified.

11:24 am
PM

thanks for all that

BE

BMO also, since it's on my screen.

BE

 We believe that the most relevant proposal for the PFE + AGN merger is the action to “limit inversions by disregarding
foreign parent stock attributable to recent inversions or acquisitions of U.S. companies.” “For the purposes of
computing the ownership percentage when determining if an acquisition is treated as an inversion under current law,
today’s action excludes stock of the foreign company attributable to assets acquired from an American company within
three years prior to the signing date of the latest acquisition.” (Source: https://www.treasury.gov) Allergan is the
product of multiple recent acquisitions in the U.S., including the acquisition of Forest Labs, which closed on July 1,
2014 for $31Bn (equity consideration of $20.6Bn, $7.1Bn cash, and $3.3Bn in assumed debt). Similarly, on March 17,
2015, Actavis acquired Allergan for $77Bn: $40Bn cash, $35Bn equity consideration, and $2Bn assumed debt.
Immediately prior to the Forest lab deal closing, Actavis’ market cap was about $39Bn. Based on our initial
understanding of the Treasury’s recent proposals, Allergan’s market cap that would be used to compute the percentage
foreign ownership of PFE + AGN will not be enough to exceed the 60/40 inversion threshold, and may not even be
enough to reach the 80/20 threshold. If the Treasury’s actions also apply to Actavis’ acquisition of Warner Chilcott in
2013, then inversion is out of the picture for Pfizer. Under current law, an inverted company is subject to potential
adverse tax consequences if the shareholders of the former U.S. parent (in this case current PFE shareholders) end up
owning at least 60% of the shares of the new foreign parent. Therefore, we believe that the tax benefits of the
PFE+AGN merger will likely be significantly diminished based on the Treasury’s recent actions. If Pfizer is not able to
invert and repatriate its ex-U.S. cash in a tax efficient manner to repurchase a significant portion of the 4.7Bn new
shares it will be issuing to buy AGN, then we doubt that the current deal structure, and implied valuation for AGN,
would make sense for PFE shareholders. If Pfizer still chooses to pursue Allergan for other strategic reasons, e.g. to
setup a split, our initial view is that the deal structure needs to be significantly revised.
 Many uncertainties in the proposals: We wonder if the stock calculation proposal can withstand legal challenge given that
it is targeting historical corporate actions at what appears to be an arbitrary cut-off point of three years. Clearly, these actions
seem to have been targeted to block the PFE/AGN merger. While it is difficult to predict whether the new proposals will
become formal regulations, the uncertainty associated with this merger is now significantly higher.
 With or without AGN, we maintain our Outperform rating on PFE. Our standalone valuation of PFE is $39 based on
DCF, P/E multiple, and sum of the parts; however, a value unlocking PFE split now seems less likely.

11:31 am
BE

Who can we quote here? How about HSBC.

BE

Tesco (sales +0.1%) gained momentum over Easter: Tesco's recovery looks to have continued with relative improvement over the Easter period building on the sequential improvement since Christmas. This performance is all the more encouraging as we believe market share data are currently understating the level of Tesco's sales growth given the impact of Brand Guarantee (explained in Why market share underestimates Tesco's recovery, 18 March 2016). In addition, Tesco has yet to annualise last year's store closures and we would expect sales growth to accelerate once this drag is annualised around April. Key to Tesco's recovery is that it remains the fastest growing retailer in cash terms for most of its suppliers. Higher volumes for its suppliers unlock economies of scale to be shared with Tesco, which can be invested, driving further growth in sales and profits - this is the Virtuous Circle.

Sainsbury's (sales +1.4%) continued to perform relatively well but was helped by the largest opening program of the Big4, having added c2% space in the last year. We expect Sainsbury's to come under increasing pressure as competitive intensity rises and discounters increase openings in Sainsbury's Southern heartland.

Morrisons (sales -2.3%) sales decline remains clouded by many moving parts. Within its sales decline, significant deflation, the exit from convenience, and store closures are a drag and will remain so for some time, disguising the underlying picture. However, it remains in a difficult situation, with falling total sales and it will be some time before the deal with Amazon becomes meaningful.

The Others: Asda's (sales +4.7%) performance did not improve materially and we wonder for how long this can continue without a response. M&S' growth (sales +4.2%) was stable despite losing strong Christmas trading from the 12wk period while Waitrose also enjoyed a good bounce with both likely benefitting disproportionately over Easter given their upmarket offer.

The Discounters: Both Aldi (sales +16%) and Lidl (sales +16.7%) continue to grow share but growth is slowing. Combined discounter share growth has slowed to 1.5ppts from 2.2ppts in October 2015. As we discuss in more detail within this report, the Big4 competitive response is likely to continue and intensify. It is easier for the Big4 to win back lost spend than for the discounters to win more. Moreover, the effort to achieve further gains may burden the discounters' simple business models with complexity and extra cost, eroding the differentiation of their model.

BE

Meanwhile, we have Deutsche going down to "hold" on Tesco.

1) The pension deficit funding agreement and the disposal of South Korea has
alleviated concerns on Tesco’s balance sheet. While leverage remains high,
liquidity is strong and the debate about a potential rights issue has largely
disappeared. 2) The closure of 43 unprofitable stores, and of Cheshunt HQ and
relocation of HQ to Welwyn Garden City is one of a number of ways
management is creating a “new” Tesco and driving c.£400m of cost savings.
3) Management has changed the way it works with suppliers, from being a
buying-led organisation to being more customer focused.

BE

Our 15/16 estimates are broadly in line with consensus (2% above at group
EBIT level but 6% below at EPS level due to a higher interest charge), however
our 16/17 estimates are c.10% above consensus, at both EBIT and EPS level.
With these numbers, we see 10% upside to our PT and no DPS until Feb 2020,
all else equal.

BE

Visibility on Asda’s capability to execute its price led strategy is low. Ex
Sainsbury’s retail and operations director Roger Burnley, recruited as Asda’s
new chief operating officer won’t start until October 2016, and it is possible
Asda continues to underperform for another 6 to 18 months, acting as a share
donor to the Big 3. While the timing is unclear, we still view a more intense
competitive reaction from Asda as a major downside risk for the sector.

11:33 am
BE

Our DCF based 210p PT uses a normalised 2.5% UK EBIT margin (3.1% group
EBIT margin), a 0% TG rate and a 6.0% WACC. Downside risks include a failure
to improve UK margin and FX. Upside risks include asset disposals and FX.

11:38 am
BE

Citi's Take

Blinkx has released a trading update covering the FY2016. While the revenue trend is light a strong focus on cost and cash has meant that profits and the net cash balance is in line with expectations. The big debate will be over how much to worry about the revenue miss. Our own view is that it looks largely to be down to the proactive wind-down of non-core revenues. This, ultimately, should be welcome as it leaves the group better placed to resume growth in 2017E. Investors, however, may well want to wait and see with the next update the FY results on 17 May. We rate Blinkx as a Neutral.

BE

Thomas Singlehurst is the analyst, of course. Bet he dreamed of writing phrases like "proactive wind-down of non-core revenues" when he was doing his CFA.

BE

Blinkx has indicated that FY2016 revs will be in the range of $165-m-$170m vs. Citi at $184.5m and Bloomberg consensus (albeit based on a sample of 2) at $180m. While revenue is light, the projected EBITDA loss at $(10)m-$(11)m is more in line with Citi at $(9.5m) and consensus at $(10.8m). The group expects cash of $76m vs. Citi at $76m. The inference is that while revenue is light, Blinkx has worked hard on cost control and working capital.

11:39 am
BE

Focus #1: Understanding the Revenue Trend

In January Blinkx released a statement saying that 3Q revenue was in line with management expectations but that profitability was ahead of expectations, achieving breakeven for the 3Q. If we look at the FY and 2H in this context we make two observations. First, the rate of revenue decline has clearly deteriorated 2H on 1H (c. -30% vs. -14%) and, by implication 4Q on 3Q (in part due to the natural seasonality of the business whereby 3Q is much more active than 4Q). Second, the rate of growth for the ‘exciting’ parts of Blinkx’s revenue base – namely programmatic and video – appears to have accelerated from +37% in the 1H to +66% for the FY. Put together, while the revenue miss is disappointing it does seem to be a result, in the main part, of a proactive wind-down of non-core revenues which now represent just 30% of group.

BE

Focus #2: Understanding the Profit Trends

A 1H loss of $6.8m has widened to $10m-$11m in the FY implying the 2H saw a loss of $3m-$4m. At the 3Q mark the inference was that profit was running ahead of expectations (at that point the group reached breakeven) which implies that the 4Q saw a resumption of losses. This, however, was expected: the seasonality of the business means revenue/gross margin can move up and down against a largely fixed opex base. With the 4Q smaller than the 3Q it makes sense that Blinkx moved back into slight losses. The bigger and more important point is that cost control is strong and that this has also extended to working capital management. Once revenue stabilizes, which seems imminent, the group should be in a good position to see an improvement in profits.

BE

Implications

The rapid wind-down of the group’s non-core revenue suggests the group should be in a much better position to grow its revenue base going forward. The encouraging trend in programmatic and video (now over 50% or revenue) and the scope for further cost saves suggests that current forecasts for 2017E (Citi at $2.5m EBITDA) look reasonable. Consensus at $(3)m may even be too low.

• Western Gate, the largest individual shareholder in Stock Spirits, has put forward the names of two NE Directors. It holds 9.7% stake. WG says ‘before launching this requisition, Western Gate held a series of meetings and exchanges with the Company's executive and non-executive directors, including ahead of the outcome of the “detailed ‘root and branch’ review” of its Polish operations which was initiated following the Company's latest profit warning in November 2015. The findings of this review were announced on 10th March 2016 but we believe they contain nothing new to adequately address the most serious problem in its business – the dramatic loss of market share in the core Polish market and resulting decline in revenue. Our engagement with the Board, together with the outcome of the Company’s wider strategic review, have left our very real concerns substantially unaddressed and indeed even raised further concerns regarding the Company’s new M&A strategy. Hence, we have decided to bring the matter directly to shareholders for their consideration and look forward to communicating with our fellow shareholders in the weeks ahead.’

I have been managing different companies in different countries for more than 20 years. I started my business career as a trainee at Unilever Portugal, where I stayed for 5 years, taking up different managerial positions in the sales and marketing departments. As of 1989, I worked for Nissan Portugal, initially as Head of the Marketing Department, to leave in 1994 as the Board Member responsible for sales, marketing and logistics. I was also part of the Nissan European Advertising Group.

PM

arrived in Poland in 1995 as JMD General Manager, and continued to build the company until 1999. In July 1999 I was promoted to become Member of the Executive Committee of Jerónimo Martins Holding in Lisbon. In July 2000 I decided to redirect my career and moved to South America where, as a partner at the AntFactory investment fund, I initiated the fund activities in Brazil, Mexico and Argentina. In 2001 I joined the LAEPBrasil private distressed assets fund as a Senior Partner.
In 2003 I set up a team to buy out Eurocash from Jerónimo Martins and returned to Poland where, as the Eurocash owner, I turned the company around.

BE

ate & Lyle today issued a short two-line trading update stating that its 4Q’16 (end Mar) trading performance was in line with both the expectations and the outlook included in the 3Q'16 trading update. This implies that Tate continues to maintain its guidance of full year adjusted PBT of £193mn at constant exchange rates (slightly below £193 at reported exchange rates). The statement reflects that Tate’s recovery post the operational challenges faced in FY’15 continues to progress well and we believe it carries solid momentum into FY’17. Reiterate BUY and 700p TP.

We rate Tate BUY and see scope for significant upside

Reiterate Buy. Tate has turned the corner and FY16 is an inflection point. We forecast an 11% rebound in FY17 pre-tax profits as 1-off items drop out and new SFI capacity comes online. Our benchmarking analysis with US peer Ingredion points to significant margin recovery over the next few years with upside risk from sharper execution or M&A. We expect an 8% EPS CAGR over FY15-20E driven by SFI growth. Investors are paid to wait via a 4.9% dividend yield.

Valuation undemanding - look to the future

Tate & Lyle trades on cal’2016E PE of 15.9x and EV/EBITDA of 9.4x, only slightly below its closest peer Ingredion albeit on admittedly depressed earnings. Looking out a few years valuation drops to 13.5x cal’19E PE and 7.9x cal’19E EV/EBITDA.

Tesco will report FY results (end Feb) on Tues 13th April. After joining in Sept
2014, this represents Dave Lewis' first full year. It’s been volatile from a share
price perspective, as enthusiasm for the new management and the potential
deleveraging impact from asset sales collided with the reality of earnings
downgrades, an aborted sale process for Dunnhumby and earnings and cash
flow dilution from the South Korea disposal. We continue to expect the best
relative EBIT margin development at Tesco vs. UK peers, driven primarily by
commercial gross margin gains and cost cutting. However, the share is up
35% in the past 3 months. We keep our 210p PT; downgrade to Hold
